answers.answer: well,....i just know i have now a very good reason to just lay on the couch and become a potato for the next "x" months till i conceive! lol =)

I'm no expert, but I'm just thinking back to my track days in high school. I remember a lot of girls, especially long distance runners, saying they wouldn't get their period very often due to excessive training. Its not excersise that causes irregularity in periods, its excersising too much that can cause it in many women. That's why your doctor probably said to cut back on the excersise, not to stop altogether. Actually excersising can be good to help regulate your period, but again, too much is not good when your trying to be regular and conceive. Eating healthy is always a good thing too, just make sure you get enough calories a day.

I would say everything in moderation for TTC and pregnancy. Most docs would agree that exercise a few times a week is healthy for everyone. Overdoing anything is not a great idea. As far as diet goes, I would say a sensible, balanced variety of foods to maintain a healthy lifestyle (without obsessing about every little thing :)). Good luck!

I really didn't think I was doing much of either.  I was only doing 50 minutes max, 6 days a week, and non of it was intense or vigorous.  It was 20 minutes of jogging the dog in the morning and MAYBE a 30 minute elliptical.  I know I was restricting some fat from my diet, but I had really been making an effort to do everything moderately.  I am having a hard time believing that it was the exercise.  I'm normal weight for my height.
Oh, and it hasn't worked for 2 months...I prob need to give it longer, just getting frustrated that that might not be the reason.

my doc said stop running too for estrogen purposesI did and got pg and carried to termyou may also want to see how "low fat"  you are.  Your body needs some fat to process all things.I too did "low fat"  and to get and stay preggo I switched to about 30 percent fat - it seemed to help

Did you do any exercising?  If so what are some examples and how long, intensity, etc?  I'm just so confused.  I have tried to start eating more fat...it's just so hard to watch my bady get fatter.  I now have cellulite where I had no idea I had even had fat before.  It it gets me preggers, I'm ok with that, but I just feel like I'm wasting my time right now doing the wrong things.  Thank you so much!!  It really helps to hear someone else actually going through this.  Everyone I know is regular except my sister.  She has PCOS, but she is still lean, has two kids with no problems getting pg, and ovulates every cycle.  Her cycles are just 35-40 days long.
Have you been tested for PCOS?  It's hereditery and can come in the most minor of symptoms.  Irregular periods is the most common.
Don't give up.. I exercise pretty often as well (60min about 5x a week) nothing strenous either. I've been trying to concieve since last Febuary (05) and only just got lucky. Just don't give up

Thanks everyone:)  I won't give up...I'm definitely a fighter:)  I only had my FSH levels tested...the dr did a bunch of other tests and she said she really doeesn't believe that I have PCOS.  I, on the other hand, am not so convinced, and that's why I am frustrated with wasting my time getting fat, which in fact can make PCOS worse.

Ask your Dr to check your insulin levels. Do you know what your estogen levels are/what they should be?For those who don't know PCOS can have stages like diabetes-you DON'T have diabetes but it messes w/your insulin levels which messes with the estrogen and causes you to produce too much testosterone. woo that was textbooky huh...anyway they would put you on metformin or a pill like it and make all your hormone levels balanced.Basicly your estrogen would be very low and testosterone very high.

I had no idea!  I pee all the time, and sometimes have wondered if I have diabetes.  Well, my estrogen level on Aug 15 was 50 and she figured when I go back in the end of November it will be around 200.  I really think that's it, but no, nothing like that was checked.  If it's low again, I'm going to an RE.  My husband is 37 and doesn't want to be having children when he's 50...lol.  My dr doesn't know my husband's age, prob figures he's my age (I'll be 25 in a few weeks), so not really thinking it's a timely matter.  Anyway, you have such a good point...do you think I should go to an RE earlier???  You are so wonderful, by the way, as are all women on this site.  Thanks to all and sticky baby dust!

I didn't do anything - nadaI know it was hard to watch cellulite appear (i was a regual 100 pounder and hated the idea of getting fat)  but it was SOOO worth it.  and I ran a marathon 5 months after giving birth

When you say your "DR" do you mean OB- regular physician-or RE?If I were you I would go to a fertility specialist and they will give you all the blood work tests to have done and tell them about your sister so it will be a priority check you may get your answers.  If you don't have it you're already there and they will proceed to the next level of fertility tests.Lots of luck to you!!

question: I know many of you know my story, but I have a question.  My dr said to stop running and only exercise moderately 30 minutes 3-4 days a week to try to get my estrogen back up so I can get regular.  If you knew me, you would realize how hard that is. I started doing online research and found so many contradicting articles on this topic.  Some say its exercise, while other drs say it calorie intake that delays your period. Any opinions?
title: exercise or diet when TTC?
